You define the <leader> by `let mapleader = ","` command. The default is "\", not "/".
You said you type :\ff are you putting the colon in?
in my .vimrc I have:
so inside vim if I do:
:\fff  (then hit enter)
nmap <leader>fff :FufFile **/<CR>
I get this: E10: \ should be followed by /, ? or &
Basically your "nmap <leader>fff :FufFile **/<CR>" command means, when you type "\fff" in normal mode, vim does the same as if you typed ":FufFile **/" and then hit enter.
You shouldn't type colon in front of \fff. It's normal mode mapping (because you do nmap). When you type colon, you go to command mode.

Then you can use something like "cmap fff FufFile **/". This way you will be able to type ":fff" and you will get the ":FufFile **/" in your command line.
